job_title: Customer Service Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: Hands down the best company I've ever had the privilege of working for! Not only does everyone treat each other with the utmost respect, but the company consistently gives back to employee's in every way they possibly can and beyond with an unbelievable amount of benefits. If I were in a situation where I was rich, I'd still choose to work for this company if they asked me for the help, and this is not loyalty won over easily. They paid way more in base salary than they needed to, offered a completely work from home environment which was insanely well organized, had nearly every procedure and operation seamlessly on auto pilot, and had the best and smartest individuals I've ever been able to work alongside. I would work for them again immediately should they every wish to employ me back, and with no hard feelings from what I'm about to list as a con.
cons: Due to big tech layoff's caused by the ever changing economy during mid 2022, it's of no surprise that financial markets were hit the hardest, and as a result executive leadership had to make the impossible call of letting 1,100 amazing employee's go. While it's very difficult to accurately predict the future and while Coinbase has acknowledged and learned from it's mistake of attempting to grow to quickly as a major goal for 2022, the only con I would have to add is that this still unfortunately did happen. Making growth a major goal for 2022 then not only being able to meet that goal but needing to then do the opposite and downsize every individual they'd spent Q1 and Q2 of 2022 building is not a thing you'd hope to predict wrong.

review_title: Good place to learn about crypto and leave ...
pros: Best place to learn about crypto with reasonable (yet volatile) compensation. A lot of diverse bets, hopefully some of those find product market fit. Many ex-CB folks go on to start web3 startups, CB really opens your eyes to the possibilities within crypto.
cons: Several bad patterns seen here. Not data-driven but very gut driven. No feedback loops on product launches, PMs will find ideas on crypto-twitter and launch them. The main app and wallet now feels like a kitchen sink of poorly tested features. Exec team (esp CEO) operate like robots and have built a super transactional mercenary culture. Town halls feel like a recorded podcast. None of this is a statement on crypto itself which I'm still bullish on despite the massive volatility and uncertainty in the past year.

job_title: Senior Onboarding Analyst in Portland, OR
pros: • Competitive pay + benefits • Cross-functional communication

pros: - The pay and benefits are amazing! - I really believe that Coinbase had created a well oiled machine when it comes to remote work- from onboarding virtually to remote work norms. - Brian being a founder CEO is a cool experience, and he has shown great leadership throughout a trying crypto market. - Depending on your role and team, you can have great work life balance.
cons: - If you are not very familiar with crypto and web3, think long and hard before you decide to start working in the space. The learning curve is STEEP and the industry is still relatively new and evolving very quickly, which can make it tough to ever feel like you’re up to speed. - Crypto/web3 is very volatile. Coinbase has proven to be a leader in the space, but a rocky 2022 market resulted in plummeting stock prices and layoffs. This isn’t Coinbase’s fault, just a reality of the industry. - Priorities change too frequently. I had countless experiences where I would begin to work on a project, only to be told a few weeks later that the project was being deprioritized and I’d be working on something else instead. Very frustrating. - Remote work has its perks, but it is tough to feel connected. This is true for any remote first company. I was under the impression when I signed my offer letter that my team would get together around once per quarter, but I ended up only seeing meeting them once after a whole year of working there (offsites kept getting canceled at the last minute).

pros:
If you're a compliance professional, this job pays well.

Good internal resources for learning about crypto, particularly if you're coming into Coinbase without prior knowledge.
cons:
The company is extremely unfocused, and there's little cohesion between teams that are working on cross-functional projects or objectives.

If you care about gender equality, this place will probably disappoint and annoy you occasionally. I've worked in male dominated industries historically, but this is the first time I've really felt like a fish out of water. There's always low-key sexist stuff getting posted to social channels, and because of the "no politics" rules that mostly mean "don't talk about social justice type issues," I'm afraid to even raise the issue. Our COO literally thinks women should just accept "you're too aggressive" critiques from men while also recommending we deal with aggressive people with grace, which I don't need to know, but do - because there's a lot of out of touch, drink-the-koolaid type emails sent our way, for some reason. I have my own personal issues which may not be systemic, but my general feeling has been that I'm not taken as seriously as male colleagues, even in cases where I have more relevant experience on a topic. Kind of stinks.

There isn't a great "remote first" culture here, either. I go extended periods of time not talking to anyone at all. Communication is not great in my org, either.

review_title: Trade your soul for a nice bank account
pros:
Comp package is great, definitely in the top tier of the tech world. Monthly stipends on top of that.

Fully remote if that's your thing.

Recharge days/weeks are nice, all things considered.

Modern tech stack.

Lots of social and networking events. People here are pretty passionate about Crypto and it shows.
cons:
Insane expectations around worklife balance. 55+ hours seems to be somewhat expected. I've had 2 week sprints with over 100 hours of work scoped out (on top of any meetings/last minute requests from upper management, etc). I told my manager I was overloaded once and their reply was "I thought you wanted to be the man?" 

Burnout here is crazy. I've done multiple all nighters here over the last year and I'll see most of my team on at 1 or 2 AM. I've been in meetings where people casually mention not having a life since joining Coinbase and phrase it like a joke, but it's so obvious from the looks on their face.

Instead of solving root issues, Coinbase instead decides to throw bodies at it and hope for the best. We have way too many cooks in the kitchen.

Throw meritocracy out of the window. I was called a bar raiser for my line of work and have been told I was "performing at a higher level" but was passed on a promotion with the primary reason being that I wasn't in my role for long enough (this was explicitly mentioned multiple times during my official review). There are no clear lines to distinguish the difference between levels.

review_title: Great place to work if all you care about is money
job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Coinbase is a fast-paced environment with a healthy engineering culture that offers the opportunity to work on industry-leading products used by millions of customers. The company offers good benefits and has transitioned well to a remote-first culture during COVID. Despite leadership problems, the company is doing well due to it's strong market position.
cons:
Coinbase suffers from a lack of competent leadership. The most notable example of this is Brian Armstrong's recent actions in response to an employee walkout because he refused to make a simple statement supporting black lives (like most other companies were doing at the time). Instead of learning from the situation and listening to employees, he publicly asked those who disagreed to leave and banned open discussion from the company slack and AMAs. This was an extreme and unnecessary step that caused high stress and conflict within the company in the midst of a pandemic. Worse, it alienated minority employees and actively undermined belonging and inclusion work being done. This was the largest unforced error by leadership, but not the first (see also the Chicago office and Neutrino acquisition).

Coinbase also has an unhealthy self-described "intense" work culture. Work-life balance is poor and burnout is common. In my experience the people who are most successful and get promotions here are the people working long hours and weekends. If you want to have a manageable workload and a rich life outside of work this is not the right company for you.

review_title: Coinbase executives treat their employees and customers like they are disposable.
pros: Great pay and benefits. However, that’s about it.
cons: The onboarding was spotty and the training, specific to my role was lacking. I found that there was a lot of over-promises and talk about everyone working as a team. However, in theory, that wasn’t the case. Customers would call with basic questions and either be met with too much information (usually not related to their questions) or generic answers that didn’t address their issues. QA seemed to be focused on hitting certain criteria but the results were skewed towards policies that were not helpful. The training wasn’t sufficient and the learning environment was hectic and felt extremely rushed. Resources were outdated and archaic. Which was surprising because with a few enablement tools, the material would have been easier (and more efficient) to navigate. Overall, the pay didn’t outweigh the oversights of poorly executed support tools.

review_title: You'll just be a replaceable cog in this toxic corporate greed machine
pros:
Fully Remote w/ tools to support that
Talented coworkers
Benefits
cons:
The most toxic work environment I’ve ever encountered. 
Needing recharge weeks because your employees are so burnt out is not a perk, it’s a red flag. 
The wrong people are promoted and recognized, and promotions are only based on who your manager is and how well they like you. 
They hire tech bros as managers who are awful with people and have no understanding of the actual work their teams are doing. It’s all about metrics that are actually made up and mean nothing, and then trying to get on upper management's good side so you aren't axed next. 
They do not care about upward feedback so the bad managers will just float along forever. If you speak up, you'll be put on HR's radar as problematic and that's the beginning of the end. 
They get rid of the wrong people and reward the wrong people, and upper leadership are robots who don't care. You cannot relax while working here.

review_title: Room for a lot of improvement
pros: I really enjoyed my immediate coworkers and work from anywhere
cons:
The culture was shocking. I have worked for large tech organizations before and have never seen anything as toxic as the culture here. It was uncomfortable to speak up or voice any dissenting opinions. It often felt like we were just burying our heads to ignore all the internal issues and acting as if things were great which was eventually problematic. 

The expectations set for employees lead to rapid burnout. To address this leadership publicly called the culture "intense" which does not fix anything but instead makes it feel like there is no hope for change. Recharge weeks were great but did not solve for the daily stress that was causing burnout the other 12 weeks of the quarter. It felt like we were expected to work at all cost for 12 weeks before we were given permission to rest. Sprint and recharge only works if you have healthy guidelines and expectations set to help employees navigate their mental health and work life balance during the sprints. I was also really frustrated by HR leadership stating that 40 hour work weeks should not be the expectation when employees voiced concerns over burnout.

review_title: Overall great experience; wish they took a stand on human rights issues; high-level poor budgeting cost me my job
job_title: Customer Support Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Great culture and, by and large, I got to work with some incredible people

- Excellent benefits and compensation

- Remote-first, and one of the early companies to embrace this
cons:
- Very superficial when it comes to taking a stand on social and human rights issues, even towards their mission statement of promoting financial freedom through crypto. While they love to tout GiveCrypto.org, they truly didn't spend much energy on this.

- High-level budgeting mistakes cost me and 1,100 other highly capable and top-performing people our jobs. Many of these people had been with Coinbase for 4+ years. Unbelievably disheartening after growing so much, and feeling at the top of my game with big ambitions, to be dropped with absolutely no notice, no time to connect with peers. Just cut right out. Based on interviews with some of the execs, it is clear that this was planned out well in advance.

pros: People are (were) excited and young. Offices are nice. Pretty standard tech benefits if you are one of the people CB hires fully. Note: It is not uncommon to start as Independent Contractors with much lower pay so CB saves on taxes, before hiring fully on to their same team with same workload but then with a normal SF/NYC salary.
cons:
Where to start.. Let's try chronological the last year or so:

Last Summer: crypto was swelling and company was ideating lots of new expansion. Covid policies were solid and executed well, and remote work was going great. Everyone was pretty optimistic. CB still seemed innovative.

Last Fall: expansion frenzy begins (excessive hiring). NFT initiatives and other business units popping up like crazy ahead of new year. Execs spend tons and tons on travel, lobbying, and M&As. Everyone is struggling to keep up with break-neck scaling. Some burnout, but just a push to EOY right?

Winter/Spring 22: People start getting coerced to come in to offices and offsites. Most of these become Covid spreader events. Especially after Omicron. But CB does them more and more anyways. Initiatives from Fall start falling short and people start winging things beyond procedures/plans to deliver something.

Summer (recently): Covid rules get thrown out the window and simplified to "you don't need to be vaccinated but if you feel sick just don't come to work". They only are making you test negative and be vaxx'd for offsites and travel since other countries largely require these. Employees brace for months of offsites at "the most convenient office for most important teams" which is just really everyone rotating into the SF office to work at a big table together with their team and "collaborate". Also the 20% layoffs. Also no meals in offices. Also the "postponement" of intern return offers. Also huge spends on unnecessary Exec privileges while not paying multiple vendors, contracts, etc. for months (maybe a few million worth at this rate). Also the performance/top performer bonuses and promos to try keeping some around through EOY or maybe to make others who didn't receive them dissatisfied enough to quit before CB has to do more layoffs. CB is no longer the innovator in crypto they think they are but instead the most basic US provider who can barely keep that chugging along or fix their People Ops.

review_title: It was a disaster. If I joined a few years earlier or later it might have been different.
pros:
- Invested heavily in having the best technology for talent in the industry
- Great benefits - Salary, insurance, pension, WFH set up, crypto education programmes
-If stock ever recovers it is best in class RSU offering(down about around 70% ytd)
-Staff hired pre hypergrowth are high performers and some of the nicest people you will ever meet
- Interesting industry, engineers in particular were very excited to engage
- Some strong leaders like Greg, Stephanie to name a few
- While the handling of the redundancy and pulled offers was poor the actual compensation was very generous.
-Company is positioned really well in the market, if they can use the crypto winter to fix their internal management, culture and operational problems it can still become the dream company I thought I was joining.
cons:
I think the easy way to sum it up is it grew way too fast. I am sure this wasn't the strategy but the hiring ended up being hyper focused on FANG and also on under levelling(Directors coming in at senior management and management).  It was a mess.

- Information: It was impossible to get the right information at the right time. I am talking basics like your targets. DRI's for critical support and information were changing constantly.

-Serious regional issues: Leaders responsible for multiple international spots. Investment and programmes focused on where the biggest fire is. New countrys opened based on a singular hire versus a strategy.

-Incompetent and political mid to senior management.  My manager told me we could ignore the company targets as she communicates to leadership that she she changed them. At the end of quarter she asked me to justify why we had not hit the company goals. 


-Very strange practices from HR on performance: My manager was friends with a person in my team and changed his target mid quarter as he was trending to hit under 50%. As his probation was coming up naturally wanted to protect her friend.


In the following quarter my manager handed her notice when it was clear she would have been asked to leave. Shortly after the person in my team who was not delivering  did not log in for 3 days. When I suggested this was not acceptable behavior my manager got me disciplined with HR(On her notice after her own performance was under par). It was the most bizarre experience I have had.

- Bad publicity from people externally trying to damage the brand and CB choosing to ignore versus defend the company.

- Public spats: People within company choosing external petitions to attack leadership instead of working internally to improve the place. Leaders countering publicly versus internally.

review_title: It's a VC value factory. Not a company with real values.
pros: If you came for the money. I mostly learned about the startup business model while I worked here and who it benefits. Made good money, had a nice view of the city, met a few movers and shakers in the bay area. All the things I no longer consider important for a good life.
cons:
Leadership are just parrots for Brian's narrow biases. There wasn't anything kind or passionate or experienced about the one-dimensional leadership team scraped together from successful non-leadership roles in FAANG offices. They were merely following the advice of any trending book on startups and looking inward for direction. 

The mantra was to keep the business in growth mode while protecting runway funds. People, customers, ethics... none of that was a concern as long as expenses were down and customer numbers were up.

Any mention of racism or other internal issues was met with a stern response and eventual exit door with an NDA and some spending money.

review_title: Hard work but fun, lots of growth opps but need more formal mentorship
job_title: Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Industry and company growth is insane!
-Very strategic company
-Focused on striving for improvement - there have been so many changes in my short time here from how to write better OKRs to remote-first best practices to re-orgs. This is a company that is extremely thoughtful.
-Hard to beat the perks (fun gifts and swag, recharge days, events even in a virtual world)
-Comp structure updates / equity grants are actually worth something
cons:
-Lack of formal mentorship. The only person who is really 'in my corner' is my manager. But if you're like me and have a manager who is a first-time people manager, that's not that helpful.
-Growth is so rapid that it can be hard to find your footing/understand how your work and your role fits into the org
-As much as we're growing, the team is still lean. You need to prioritize and shield your time, otherwise people will pull you in 100 directions and it's hard to say no when you're still new
-Not enough feedback. I have only gotten feedback when I specifically solicit it. I would like to see people using forums like Lattice more to shout out great work.
-The way internal comms are handled is sometimes distasteful. For instance, when we had articles in NYT that claimed we were not treating certain POC employees fairly, the comms we received from Paul/Kim were basically "that's factually incorrect. There is evidence to the contrary." I understand we need to be careful about what we say, but it came off as truly disrespectful to people who have experienced mentally difficult work situations without acknowledging that what they experienced could be real (and also may have been handled in a way that was appropriate at the time by Coinbase). It's really easy to make POC feel like racism is in their head, and I was horrified that Coinbase took that path in dealing with the situation. That was a low moment for me at the company.

pros: Good pay and benefits, which somewhat compensate for the shitshow we have to deal with.
cons: There is nothing that is consistent or constant in this company. Training is next to none. Managers make decisions and implement them too hastily without even having all the details etc. leaving the employees confused, looking for answers to even be able to do their job. The list of cons is endless.

- Good CEO
cons:
This place will work you to the bone and come performance review time tell you you are "ok". 

60 hour weeks are pretty normal. If you are a hard-working engineer like I was then this won't discourage you. However, the lack of acknowledgment of the work you put in and over-delivering on all of your objectives is very normal at Coinbase. Only about 2 in 10 engineers "exceed" expectations and a lot of this is based on politics in my experience here.

Also if you are looking to join and think the pay equity is a good idea then you have to accept the fact that you can outwork someone by 3x who is doing the bare minimum and they will be compensated in the exact same way as you.

comp is good.

What you get in the interview and what you get when you start are like 2 different companies.

1. they tell you that everyone works hard but the company respects work-life balance.
2. your manager paints a great picture of the support and engagement you will get.

after starting, it became clear that the message is "get stuff done, nobody cares what the challenges are." that apparently that includes whether or not you got any direction or guidance, or even were told what was needed. in most meetings, people are clearly tired, frustrated and negative. 

My manager knew who was I was before I joined, but after - I'm not sure they could pick me out of a lineup. I see my manager every 6 weeks. This is the most disengagement I've experienced and i have to say it's really difficult - psychologically this is a very unhealthy environment. There's no support, a lot of politics, HR is nowhere to be seen. 

On paper this all seemed like it was going to be an awesome experience - growth, learning. It feels like it was a mirage.

review_title: What it is really like working with Coinbase
job_title: Customer Support Analyst II in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Best place I have ever worked! Even though we've had a hiring spree - the leadership and hiring managers have a real talent for putting the right people together. We fit because we all have a similar vision, personality type and velocity. You can truly get things done and It's a pleasure to work amongst my kind. I've progressed lightyears in a short time and was given trust and space to grow. It's synergy and cutting edge work culture without the mental pitfalls of silicon valley. I'm truly honoured to be part of the team and am confident in my leadership ( and I don't trust any leadership). Coinbase has a common good vision and a plan and it's executing it every step of the way fighting on all fronts. You may not be able to see it as there's loads of trash online but as I can see there's the method to it all.
cons: Coinbase has provided the best possible condition for their employees they can possibly achieve within their constraints. No real cons. High velocity all the time but for the right type of person it means being in your element.

pros:
-Welcoming culture, that doesn't feel fake and manufactured like many other places. The vibe: Accept you as you are, but keep your politics and other irrelevant garbage at home.
-Excellent pay & benefits (seriously top notch for both)
-Permanent work from home, with policies and a culture to support and empower that

-The "Sprint" mentality means that there is often a false sense of urgency, and the stress that goes with that
-The 4 weeks of shut down make it feel impossible to take any other time off

pros:

review_title: Sociopathic Management Ruining Foolproof Cash Cow Company
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Full disclosure: I made a few million here just by being in at the right place and time where my option strike price was basically nothing. Which is awesome, life changing for those of us who lucked into that. I can't, in good faith, recommend anyone new to work here though.

- Above average pay + equity comp (though stock only goes down)
- Remote work is nice
- Used to have really great perks, may one day again
- Modern dev practices
- Good diversity if you care about that
- Sounds sexy on your resume I guess?
cons:
Company has pretty much been in a downhill spiral since about 4 months before it went public. This has nothing to do with the decisions about "no politics at work" and everything to do with outwardly hostile, sociopathic senior management that was all hired about this time.

As an engineer you will spend 2-10 hours of your week interviewing new candidates (apparently the 'hiring' team is just a passthrough), more time learning new interviews (we all have to learn 20 new ones by the end of the year!) and if you're anything past a junior engineer about 20 more hours a week will be interviews. Oh and if you're in charge of bootcamp mentoring or on call another 10-20 hours is gone from your day. So you then have to work evenings and weekends or your work just won't get done. And don't think they won't notice if you skip a Saturday, they will.

Don't expect your manager to help either because they're required by the new rules to spend 50% of their time on new hire headhunting and interviews and if you ever see your manager's schedule it's meetings 9-5 anyway. They'll message you at 8 PM asking you to do something, have a weekly sync with you where they tell you you're off track and need to work harder or you're fired in 60 days (New 'on track pulses' every quarter to keep you motivated by fear) and throw new work at you and say 'figure it out'.

Upper management sits around spewing nonsense about NFTs and how we're totally going to be saving starving African farmers with crypto any second now. Self-righteous lip service while they basically hold employees hostage to 80 hour work weeks with their stock option vesting schedule. You're here making the execs (and if you're lucky yourselves) and Chinese speculators richer, don't kid yourselves.

Oh and there's no QA or testing. Nope, zero. Don't believe in it. Instead we sneakily try to fix things in production by constantly firefighting with 'incidents'. I can't tell you all the shady borderline illegal things I've been asked to do to cover this up either. Couldn't actually test things, better put that on the engineers too. 


If this all doesn't put you off though I will admit, great place to make money. If the stress doesn't kill you by 40 you can retire.

pros: Comp before stock tanked. Benefits
cons: DRI culture = under the bus. So many people in leadership positions looking for someone to blame for their own failures. I’m the sole SME in my lane and leadership has not listened to a single recommendation and keeps directing more and more micromanagement on my plate. Looking to get out ASAP.  Hope I leave them all hanging.

pros: I love everything about Coinbase - I want to retire here.
cons: I honestly have none - Coinbase has changed my entire life!

pros:

When you are in nesting taking calls, they say you can ask for help and you will be helped. No-one barely got helped by any supervisors or sme’s. Imagine not getting your 3 first paychecks and no-one is working to resolve this issue? I would stay away if I were you.

review_title: Unmatched Career Acceleration at Formation of an Industry
pros:
- Career Acceleration: Opportunities for career growth at Coinbase are unmatched. There is infinite cool work to be done and executing at a high level unlocks even more opportunity. If you are a high performer this is THE place to be working right now. 
- Formation of an Industry: Coinbase will go down in history as the first big crypto company. Once in a lifetime opportunity to be there as the foundation of crypto is built.  Feels like very week I am a meaningful part of a “first” for the industry. 
- Top Talent: talent level is very high and only getting better as we grow and hire super high quality talent.
- Fun: people here are a bunch of fun to work with, which is the cherry on top.
cons: - Work-Life Balance: Given it is a crypto summer, the whole company is working very long days/nights. It’s part of the territory of being at a hypergrowth startup and we are hiring as fast as possible to address it so expect it to smooth out.  Leadership is doing some cool initiatives like giving out recharge days and approving additional headcount so confident it will get better!  If you want a 9 to 5, this may not be a perfect fit.

job_title: Senior Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Intelligent people and interesting product ideas. Coinbase likes top shelf meaning the best advisors, applications and technology. Compensation reboot leveled the playing field for the most part good money and benefits. The best part about Coinbase for me was it taught me what’s non-negotiable in an employer and working environment. It made me realize the things I need in order to be successful. I now know my limits by seeing them crossed. Not an ideal way to learn, but learned nonetheless.
cons: Political. Everyone is trying to get to the top regardless of obstacles. Constant turnover. Employees and entire teams would just disappear and nothing said. Bring your game face because you will be challenged every step of the way by those not in your field and without reason. There are ego’s, judgements and constant finger pointing which prevents innovation and brainstorming. There’s always a power struggle playing out between management. There is nothing humble about Coinbase. Poor work life balance in certain departments. If you can find and connect with the good people then it’s doable.

review_title: Everything I could have hoped for, and more
pros:
This company truly cares about the employee experience in a remote first environment. I previously worked at another 'big tech' company and had felt completely forgotten. Here, there are regular online hangouts, events, perks sent to us, etc.

As others have mentioned, growth is insane and learning opportunities are abundant. Coinbase truly has some of the top talent in crypto - we are regularly called upon to solve problems that can't just be searched on google.
cons:
Career development feels very vague. I have no issues with this right now though as I am relatively new and very happy with salary - but it definitely feels like there is simply too much work to even think of spending time on career conversations.

Company's internal comms can sometimes be unclear (e.g. comp 3.0). Unclear communication leads to unnecessary conflict amongst teammates.

review_title: A place to grow your career and make huge impacts
pros: Coinbase is an amazing place to work for a number of reasons. The company is dedicated to its mission and all employees are united in building something that will change the world as we know it. The hiring bar is high so I work with some of the most intelligent, creative and driven people I have ever met. The company is in hyper-growth so there is a lot of work to do and it can be hard at times but the executive team rewards hard work. We have a lot of great benefits and perks as well as company recharge days. We also have a very competitive compensation approach where you are rewarded for going above and beyond. It is exciting to be part of something so potentially impactful. A real once in a lifetime opportunity.
cons: We are moving very quickly and that can be hard but it will be worth it.

review_title: Fun, fast-paced, rewarding but tough work
pros:
* Extremely fast-paced, with lots of problems to tackle
* Company in fantastic financial position
* Very competent and experienced leadership team
* Brilliant co-workers to work with and learn from
* Good regulatory position - takes regulation very seriously
* Clear focus on goals - minimal political distractions (you may know the history here)
cons:
* Difficult workload, high stress, and not great work life balance
* Highly regulated industry adds huge time/cost to projects
* Too many cooks in the kitchen for certain initiatives; lacking clear DRIs/accountability on certain initiatives
* Company seems a little reactionary to competition
* Although the company has good product leadership, huge amount of legal/compliance influence on things which can add time/cost to projects

review_title: Best job and company in my career so far
pros:
Such a positive change for me and my career. I must say that I'm lucky to be a part of the Coinbase team. 

I feel that my work is valued and management cares for me. Career development opportunities. Amazing benefits. 

Great work-life balance! The majority of employees can choose working full time from home or from the office or to have a combination of the two. I was commuting for hours everyday in my previous jobs and it's great to have so much extra time now, but still the option to go to the office if I wanted.

The crypto filed is very exciting and you will be part of a hyper-growth industry.
cons: The hyper-growth industry can be challenging sometimes.

review_title: Doing impactful work while being entirely remote
pros:
- If you're like me and like a fast-paced environment, this is a definite pro.
- The sheer breadth of work keeps you on your toes, pushing you to learn new things.
- Lots of opportunities for team work.
- Working with great colleagues and managers, who don't feel like they're halfway across the world, even if they are!
- Doing impactful work. Even though you might be here less than a year, the work you'll be doing will have an immediate impact.
- The company culture is radically candid, and learning and efficiency oriented. If you like getting things done, while learning new things, and doing work with a cohesive unit - this is the place for you!
cons: - Normal start-up drawbacks like being fast paced environment, changing requirements, wearing multiple hats, long hours...etc. It is what keeps it fun though.

review_title: Coinbase isn't perfect, but it's pretty great
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I am a woman at Coinbase and I personally have experienced quite a bit of growth opportunity and ownership during my time at Coinbase. The people here are highly intelligent and considerate. We have a high bar for integrity, and in my experience, the leadership is humble, open to feedback and wants to improve. We've recognized that there is a need for more experienced leadership (any startup I've worked with has gone through this phase) and have been working to address that by hiring a Chief Legal and Risk officer, as well as an experienced Engineering Manager. We're also continuing to hire for experienced leaders across the organization and training existing managers. 

As a woman in technology, I've experience the frustration of being interrupted when speaking, having a man parrot my comment in a meeting then get credit for the idea, having to justify everything I do with metrics. I've experienced this at every single company I've worked for. Not just Coinbase. In fact, in my experience the CEO, leadership and employees at Coinbase care more about changing this and improving the environment than any other place I've worked.
cons: We're going through some growing pains of being resource-constrained with a ton of work to do. Because we're growing so quickly, sometimes communication wires can get crossed which can result in misunderstandings.

review_title: Love my work, love my team, love this company!
pros:
- Innovative, forward thinking people. Everyone is seriously so smart here, it's amazing. 
- The culture is one of transparency, and due to that I feel trusted by the executive team. 
- I love the work I'm doing; it's interesting and continues to develop and change as the business does. 
- My direct management team is amazing as well - they are open and listen to us, but no-nonsense about things that require it. They also bring humor and fun to the every day, which I love. 
- The benefits are really great on multiple levels and I haven't been offered a better overall compensation package in my career. We're well taken care of in the office, too!
- A ton of opportunities for learning and for growth.
cons:
- Lack of a defined and clear training program for my position, but something I am accustomed to in the startup world, and honestly no real complaints about it. Just something that needs to be developed!
- I am not a fan of the open office concept. This is probably only a noticeable issue right now because the PDX office is still small space-wise and there aren't quiet places to retreat to until we move into a larger space (soon).

pros:
The people here are incredible, so welcoming and friendly and will do everything they can do help you learn and develop whether you need to learn about our mission and technical aspect or need to know where things are in the building.

Team work, supporting each other,  a passion for our mission and how we can impact the world, a focus on employees careers and development both personal and professional and a belief that everyone is a grown up and is working hard and doesn't need to be micromanaged. 
Inclusivity, there is a built in passion for creating a diverse and inclusive workforce globally. There are so many inspirational females in leadership roles and an inclusive workforce it is clear this is at the forefront of their minds when scaling the business.
Flexibility - they allow flexible working which is great when you have meetings with international offices later/ earlier and need to be flexible with timings of your day.

These are just teething problems of a startup and even in my time here I have seen the improvements made since I joined.

review_title: Work with incredible people: A+ / Career advancement for women: D-
pros: Coinbase hires some of the most intelligent, talented, motivated, and fun people. Your coworkers can easily become your best friends, and you can constantly learn new and interesting things from your peers inside or out of the office.
cons: The unconscious pro-male bias is out of control. If you're a woman, here are things that do not matter to Coinbase: related career experience, time with the company, being the best at what you do despite being challenged and undermined by others with more "seniority", or doing work that directly brings the company huge cost savings. You'll get paid less than your male colleagues, passed over for promotions, feedback that amounts to "you should just be nicer", and eventually, after learning HR's involvement only makes your situation worse, you'll leave.

review_title: Poor people management and lack of clear career path
pros: Group of the best and motivated people. Coinbase has been successful in attracting talent. Plenty of upside.
cons:
Beyond the crypto hype, Coinbase is facing some serious people management issues. It has attracted best talent from big and prestigious tech and finance firms, but those talented people are handled in a poor way. Whether it is pay, career grooming or long term retention. Needs some serious change.

Have been at Coinbase for close to a year. High turnover and lack of clear career path for experienced professionals are two consistent themes across teams.

Titles and levels are not consistent across teams. Compensation is mediocre.  Ownership and accountability lacks. People getting fired, forced to let go or feeling unappreciated because the new managers don't connect with the old employees.

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
My favorite part about Coinbase is that the company is consistently able to hear and respond to things that aren't going well. Whether it's using data to drive product decisions, increasing engineering quality, or making the organization more inclusive, I've regularly seen Coinbase make massive cultural overhauls in a matter of weeks and months, leaving the organization in a much healthier place. We definitely don't always get things right the first time, but I have full confidence that we're constantly moving in the right direction.

I think this culture really comes from the top -- Brian does an amazing job asking for feedback and then acting on it. Just recently, he sent out his personal goals for 2018 to the whole company and at the end of last year, he sent out his full 360 review to everyone, along with what he was doing to improve. This leadership flows through him, to the exec team, to managers, to ICs; it's really awesome to see.
cons: Coinbase is growing really fast -- this means communication can sometimes be a challenge.

review_title: Awesome people and an amazing mission
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Interview Process
-Tailored interview process for specific roles -- I interviewed for a senior front-end role and was tested on practical skills pertaining to my role rather than brain teasers, etc.
-Folks are constantly iterating on the interview process to make sure the candidates have a great experience

Engineering
-Very inclusive and collaborative engineering mindset -- members of other teams are happy and willing to get together and help with anything
-Immense focus on reducing duplicate efforts and code sharing (especially now that the org is growing)
-Teaching culture -- everyone is encouraged to lead code schools and there are weekly talks by external speakers (technical and non-technical)
-Tons of support and encouragement from other engineering teams to lead initiatives

General Culture
-Very authentic and humble people
-Everyone (especially leadership) is bought into the mission of creating an open financial system for the world and it shows in day-to-day interactions and decisions
-Immense focus on creating a diverse work environment with varying perspectives
-Transparency -- weekly AMAs (Ask me anything) hosted by leadership across all orgs

Benefits
-Awesome benefits (meals, commuter benefits, 401k, medical, developmental budget, etc.)
cons: Growing pains as with any company growing quickly -- however, proactive initiatives  are constantly put in place to mitigate many of these.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: I would say there are none, other than a crypto education
cons:
What is somewhat hilarious about Coinbase's Glassdoor rating is that there is an actual company OKR to make Coinbase the "best rated crypto company on Glassdoor". Rather than focus on actually developing the company culture, the leadership team is intent on making it appear as though there is a great culture.  However, the culture is one in which jerks are rewarded and those that disagree with said  jerks are either threatened about their future after Coinbase (especially in the engineering space) or those employees become too afraid to take risks. 

The other reality of Coinbase is this - the mission to "create an open financial system for the world" is not the goal. The actual goal is to make as much money as possible. Leadership would do all of us a great service by just being honest about their intentions. 

Finally, be honest about the fact that it's okay to treat people terribly internally. If it benefits the company's bottom line to keep someone in their role, that person is kept in that role regardless of how they treat others. There are people out there that are okay with that kind of experience. I'm not one of them.

pros: Coinbase has raised a lot of money and is continuing to grow fast
cons: The ultimate white bro engineering culture. D&I is incredibly tokenized (e.g., "how great is this, we've got a black candidate!"). People are constantly being fired or pushed out. Worst place I've worked. HR writes fake Glassdoor reviews whenever there's a negative review.

review_title: Incredible mission, incredible people, incredible career
pros:
• The entire company believes very strongly in crypto and building an open financial system for the world. It's not just lip service.
• If you're new to crypto, you'll find a lot of resources to help you if you're willing to jump in. It's okay to be new, most people are.
• There's so much going on, it's hard to believe a company so small is building so much at one time.
• The vision of the company is bigger than you can imagine.

cons: The company is growing so fast at this point (2018) that there are a lot of organizational growing pains. Office space is tight. You have new people joining every two weeks and so org charts are constantly changing.

- Driven, passionate and continuously learning Founder/CEO
- Transparent communication from leadership
- Constant strive toward new and improved working environments re: remote work and situations like COVID-19
- Great product with positive impact and growth
- Equity with a huge upside increasing company-wide productivity and buy-in
- Because of current vs projected scale, there are likely more opportunities for advancement than the Googles and Facebooks of the world
- Review process is fair and non-intrusive
- Constant but valuable surveying of employee feedback to see how internal processes and/or perks can be improved followed by action to make those changes
cons:
- For some the technology we utilize and implement is complicated and hard to understand causing non-technical employees to get lost and/or confused
- Constant improvement can make some employees feel whiplash
- Because we are in a business that requires compliance and regulation, there is a strong security emphasis that can stagnate and impact automation re development workflows from an ideation and creativity viewpoint
- There are disparate groups of engineers that are not looped into the overall engineering org causing difference of workflow and overall lack in uniformity which compounds the security concerns mentioned earlier and stagnates innovation greatly

job_title: Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Since Coinbase is a pioneer in a new industry, it is forced to tackle lots of interesting problems, both technical and non-technical. Most people are genuinely inspired by the mission of creating an open financial system and the company has a long-term outlook (it's not a get-rich-quick Silicon Valley scheme). The people here are hard-working, humble, and trust each other to do their work well. Aside from that they are interesting, genuine, and fun to be around.
cons: The company feels like it's becoming more top-down as it grows. Understaffed teams are struggling to keep up with the growth.

-From what I've experienced, you get a lot of autonomy to do your job but have leaders readily available to help out

Long story short this place is awesome. Not often do you get a chance to work on so much greenfield stuff.

pros:

It was amazing. In fact my wife's feedback post interview was, "whatever they did to you you need more of in your life (in reaction to me being so humbled)!"

review_title: There is a reason why people do not make it more than a year

pros: Great company perks (but you can get this at many Bay Area companies). Genuinely smart people.

review_title: Hard-working and tight-knit team. Great company culture.

pros: One of the most exciting work environments I had ever experienced. (But keep in mind this was also at the boom/bust cycle of Bitcoin, when BTC traded near $1000, and then dropped to $300.) Lots of interesting challenges around regulations, payments, consumer, and merchants.
cons: I don't think there's anything wrong with this from a business point of view, but maybe their propensity to "fire fast" is a little bit scary from a job security point of view.

review_title: Rocket ride making the world better!
pros: Part of a team and you feel it. My team really focuses on being collaborative and instilling pride and ownership in the work. We maintain our eye on the prize of making the world a better place through incredible technological advances supported from both the engineering and non-engineering sides of the house.
cons: There are growing pains, but leadership has implemented several outlets of communication to identify and address. Some systems are past capacity, but that's part of the fun in identifying and improving as a team.

pros: The benefits are great, The teams and people are welcoming, people are good at making you feel listened to
cons:
There is a difference in pretending someone is listening and them actually hearing you. 

I have been in the same position for almost two years and I am told that there is always room for career growth. However, any time reviews come around, there is absolutely no room for development. The only way you grow in your role is if they decide they want to hire someone for that role, not because we work our butts off and we deserve it. 

Recently, Quality was rolled out onto all analysts, and even though one might go above and beyond in their role, a score of 85-90% is not "good enough" to develop in career. The entire team of peers might view you as a leader, in fact your manager might even depend on you to do their job, but even then you are only thought to be _meeting expectation_. 

Which bring me to my next point, what are my expectations in my role? I don't even know what they are or what the role above me is. 

These roles are run by managers who don't even work in the same office as you, who cant see any of the hard work you put in, who refuse to make a form of metrics that are show all the work a person puts in. 

Oh and feedback, its all negative reinforcement. 

The thing that really bums me out is I LOVED this job, I easily said it was the best job I've ever had, but management is going down the drain. I have never felt so discouraged and unappreciated in a job as I do here. My mental health is being deeply affected by this bizarre place.

pros:
Amazing colleagues

Coinbase is most successful company in crypto space. Good for your resume
Stereotypical SF startup luxuries (catered meals, etc)
cons:
Went from startup to big corporation, with all the bad things that implies. Moved all decision making behind layers of middle management, restructured to remove benefits and flexibility from employees, and outsourced labor so they could fire long time employees.

- Comp far lower than average for SF, while workload is higher
- New hires don't get much equity anymore
- Employees frequently disappear overnight and nothing is spoken about them being fired, even to their own teams
- Promises of "progress, improvement" that stretch on for multiple quarters without any changes
- Low capacity for constructive feedback. Retaliatory atmosphere

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
We're all aligned around our mission to create an open financial system for the world.  It's a super-inspiring mission, and if we are successful, we will help lift billions of people out of poverty, while accelerating the pace of innovation around the world. 

One of the most exciting things about cryptocurrency is that it has the potential to create a more open and inclusive financial system — one where people are able to verify their identity through the blockchain using only information that is relevant. Parts of your identity that may lead to explicit or implicit bias are not relevant (e.g., race, gender, sexual orientation, etc.).  

We are absolutely not a run fast and break things culture — that does not work when it comes to people’s money.

Our leadership team is dedicated to creating a culture that is diverse and inclusive -- many members of our leadership team are female, one of the highest percentages in the tech industry. 

People come to Coinbase to earn their "Masters in Crypto" or start their crypto career — the "Coinbase mafia" is already one of the most impressive group of technologists, investors and entrepreneurs working in tech today. We're building products that help people own, trade, earn, and use cryptocurrency. We're not just building a company, but an entire new industry. 

Coinbase has paying customers from every walk of life, and we have to listen to their feedback at all times to keep their business. That means, we cannot just build products and services for one type of customer — we are totally motivated to represent an incredibly broad community, and if crypto is going to be as successful as people think it should be, it has to be global. That's awesome.

Lots of communications internally, so you know you're on the right track / same page as your colleagues. We have Friday morning AMAs with leadership, and we have an incredible Speaker Series, welcoming guests from across Silicon Valley to come in and share their experiences with us.  

Overall office environment is positive -- great breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks provided!
cons:
Tech / finance are historically not diverse industries. Don't repeat the same mistakes of the past, where women and minorities are left behind or don't advance at the same pace.

Would be nice for Coinbase to match 401K contributions and cover cell phone bills completely (versus a small monthly stipend).

review_title: If you are a diversity hire, stay away
pros: This may be a good first or second job in your career. If you’re an intern or someone with no family to go home to, this might be a good place to have fun and bond with others from similar backgrounds. There are many social events to keep you busy after work hours.
cons:
Leadership does not lead. They just spend a lot of time trying to make everyone feel good. There seems to be a lot of smoke and mirrors. No decisions seem to stick. There are no adults in the room that actually understand execution, as opposed to touring the talk or conference circuit. Doing it quick and dirty is often mistaken for “efficient execution”, as opposed to actually doing it right and not leaving others, usually the Customer Service folks and ultimately our customers, in a lot of pain. Cross-team work is wrought with friction because the teams are very disjointed. We do not have enough technical leaders who want to fix cross-team coordination, probably because there is no respect for that type of work. Experienced leaders have been recruited recently from other industries, like financial services, etc, and then are being set up to fail. People are being forced into the wrong roles. There is no empathy. If you are not from The Big 5 (Google, Amazon, Apple, Facebook, or Twitter) then you’ll likely be treated like an imposter because pedigree is everything. Scaling is but one problem to be solved in the world, and the fact that you may have solved problems 1000x more complex than blasting tweets will mean very little to them.

If you are a diversity hire, you may be treated like a quota, as opposed to someone who actually deserves to be there. This is because like most other tech companies, it is treated as a funnel issue, as opposed to a retention and culture issue. There is a sad lack of diversity in our product and engineering leadership, and consequently, strategic product initiatives. The folks who are there don’t seem to be very “included”. Our diversity and inclusion initiatives are being run by people, save for one, who probably have never experienced what it is like to be an underrepresented minority in tech and been one of the unlucky ones to experience discrimination first-hand. How do you actually fix the problem if you don’t know what it’s like?  The condescension is real. You’ll spend a lot of time nodding and smiling because if you get upset and speak up, it probably won’t reflect well on you. Save yourself the heartache.

What’s sad is that diversity and inclusion initiatives are so in your face that the overrepresented folks are beginning to feel excluded too. The problem is probably because there are senior leaders who don’t take it that seriously.
